In the elections held five years ago, the LDF had won 18 seats in the 27-member district panchayat. In the 75-member Kozhikode Corporation council, it won 51 seats, while the UDF was reduced to 17 and NDA seven. In the 12 block panchayats, the LDF came to power in 10 and the UDF two. Of the 70 grama panchayats, it had a majority in 42. However, the UDF had an upper hand in the municipality elections, as it won Feroke, Ramanattukara, Koduvally, and Payyoli while the LDF could come to power only in Vadakara, and Koyilandy. title: Kerala local body polls: LDF–UDF locked in a neck-and-neck battle in Thrissur; BJP could tilt the scales
text:
The district that rolled out a red carpet for the Left in the last local body polls is heading into another tightly contested battle. This time, the Left Democratic Front (LDF) is fighting to retain its dominance in Thrissur. The United Democratic Front (UDF) is attempting a comeback after two successive setbacks. And the National Democratic Alliance, buoyed by Suresh Gopi’s emphatic Lok Sabha victory, is hoping to convert momentum into seats.
Thrissur, the cultural capital of Kerala with deep political roots, comprises 86 grama panchayats, one Corporation, seven municipalities and 16 block panchayats. Historically, the UDF has had a strong presence here — especially in the city. But over the last decade, Thrissur’s political wind drifted towards Left. Group feuds and rebel trouble crippled the UDF in consecutive elections. This time, with smooth candidate selection and fewer internal fissures, the front senses a chance to regain lost ground.
Past record
In 2020, the LDF transformed Thrissur into its fortress — winning 69 of 86 grama panchayats, 13 of 16 block panchayats and 24 of 29 district panchayat divisions. The front also secured five of the seven municipalities. It was a massive sweep.
The Corporation, however, remained a cliffhanger. Both fronts secured 24 seats each in the 55-member council, while the BJP won 6. The LDF formed the council only with the support of a UDF rebel — M.K. Varghese — who was rewarded with the Mayor’s post. The UDF had missed majority by just one seat.
Obviously, the Corporation witnessing toughest fight. This time, the LDF hopes for a third straight term.  The UDF is determined to break the streak. The NDA, riding high on its parliamentary performance, is eyeing gains in the 36 divisions where Suresh Gopi led convincingly. 
An unpredictable electorate
As campaigns enter the final stretch, Thrissur’s voters remain inscrutable. Political observers see no wave — neither the Left nor the Right — only an electorate that keeps every front guessing. 
The LDF, with its ten-year governance record in both State and Corporation, projects development, welfare, and continuity as its core pitch. The UDF counters with sharp anti-incumbency claims, calling the last decade “a period of stagnation” marked by failed infrastructure and deteriorating services.
The Rahul Mamkootathil controversy, the Sabarimala gold theft, and the pitiable condition of national highway are visible talking points. But on the ground, daily concerns speak louder:

title: LDF vies for a coup in a district perceived a UDF bastion
text:
At first glance, Wayanad district appears to be a stronghold of the United Democratic Front (UDF) in view of the Congress party’s consistent victories in the Wayanad parliamentary constituency and reinforced by the high-profile contests of its leaders Rahul Gandhi in 2019 and later his sister, Priyanka Gandhi Vadra, in 2024.

title: Kerala local body polls: Neck-and-neck fight in Palakkad as BJP, UDF, LDF vie for 53 seats
text:
The electoral contest in the Palakkad Municipality promises to be fierce. The ongoing triangular battle suggests that no party is likely to secure a comfortable majority in the 53-member council.
Palakkad is in the spotlight of the State’s electoral watch, largely because the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) has held the municipality since 2015. Though the party has 28 members in the outgoing council, none are confident of repeating that tally this time.
Rivalry within the BJP has reached a boiling point, and the party would not be surprised to lose a few seats. Yet, with the  Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh’s (RSS) involvement, it is trying to present a united front.
RSS’s sway
The real question is how much sway the RSS can hold in an election shaped by personal rivalries and old scores. Still, the BJP leaders insist they are aiming for a third consecutive term in Palakkad.
The BJP’s claim may hold weight, especially given the troubles within the Congress. While the Congress insists its house is intact and stronger than last year, concerns linger that the Rahul Mamkootathil issue could hurt its prospects.
But the Communist Party of India (Marxist) [CPI(M)] appears stagnant in Palakkad. If it loses a seat or two compared to last year, the Congress may argue that the Rahul Mamkootathil issue had no impact at all.
Reaching the magic number of 27 seats will be tough for both the BJP and the United Democratic Front (UDF). BJP sources predict a haul of 20–24 seats, while the UDF insiders claim they too can secure at least 20.
Rebel candidates
Anticipating a tight contest, both the BJP and the UDF have ramped up campaigns across several wards. Results could be unpredictable in at least 15 wards, especially with the presence of a few rebel candidates.
In ward 10, BJP district secretary P. Smithesh and Congress leader K. Bhavadas are in a neck-and-neck battle. Likewise, BJP State treasurer E. Krishnadas faces a tough contest in the Pattikkara ward against the Congress’ Vinod Pattikkara.
Kerala Pradesh Congress Committee (KPCC) secretary P.V. Rajesh is contesting ward 19 against BJP’s M. Sasikumar. The BJP has allotted West Yakkara and Fort Ground wards to its ally Bharath Dharma Jana Sena (BDJS).  In the UDF, the Indian Union Muslim League is contesting nine seats.
The CPI(M) is contesting 44 wards, though nearly half of its candidates are running as Independents.

General Education Minister V. Sivankutty said that Ms. Sreelekha’s action is a violation of the model code of conduct. “Her conduct reflects her lack of knowledge in the political field. The authorities have to look into the poll code violation,” he said.
Earlier, during the campaigning phase, Ms. Sreelekha, former Director General of Police (DGP), had faced criticism over the use of the ‘IPS’ tag in her posters and campaign materials. The tag was removed in some posters, while in others it was changed to ‘IPS (Retired)’.
